A lot of twists and deaths. I feel like:
This is a wonderful second installment. Adam Driver nails his performance as a very damaged\, complex Byronic character with strong hints of Mr. Darcy. The chemistry between Kylo Ren/Ben Solo and Daisy Ridley's Rey switches from achingly beautiful to explosive as they play with and subvert the prince/princess archetype. Mark Hamill turns in the performance of a lifetime\, showing that just as in real life\, being a hero isn't all what it's cracked up to be\, but when push comes to shove\, we've got to do the heroic thing anyway.

I didn't mind that Rose and Finn's storyline did not come to a happy ending\, but that again injects a little realism. For any adventure\, even a fairy tale in space\, to live up to the name\, there has to be some risk\, and what risk would be taken in a story where everything goes right? I only wish there were a bit more chemistry between Finn and Rose\, so I could better anticipate Rose's last- and most profoundly beautiful- line in the movie.

And because books make people smarter and also make for a better moviegoing experience\, I recommend the Aftermath trilogy\, Cobalt Squadron\, Jane Eyre\, and Pride and Prejudice. Refresh your memory of regular this-galaxy fairy tales\, too\, like Snow White and Beauty and the Beast.
